reviews.author: climbclimb
reviews.comment_content:
Anthropology is fun, I like this topic so I actually quite like it lol. Linguistics is a no-no for me, I have no interest in identifying the words of Chinese. For literature, it is ok, mainly covers Green Snake, and some basic elements of cinematic actions and basic literature elements.

It is quite easy and nothing deep, each module only last 7-8 lessons, reli quite intro.
reviews.comment_teaching: The classes in Anthropology is really slow-paced, the prof breathes heavily which makes me super bored. And the class mainly surrounded by his story. Prof. Sun is kind, tho I did not listen to his classes as all, he treats students very well as he answers ad replies pretty fast when it comes to some consultations of research proposal. Prof. Ma speaks quite ok, maybe she did study in U.S before idk but overall speaking nth special about her.

Linguistics Quiz: 67.5/100 (Mean: 70.9)

Research Proposal: below mean (linguistics)
Grade: A

Surprised cuz i got below mean in linguistics and the report, want to swap to another topic but no one willing to swap with me :( I am from busi school so thats a pretty decent grade for me.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fine, I just begin watch lecture videos 2 days before lmao. And I did not even attend any linguistics lessons since I got covid during the quiz period fml, I just learnt the concepts during the morning. I did not read any readings for all modules. For Anthropology, the readings are actually useful I think since some concepts are not taught in the lecture. For literature, i got a surprisingly high marks, as I did not even read the book which are compulsory, and the quiz is all about Green Snake which are the book lol. I just immediately searched online during the quiz, and that's definitely fine for people who are lazy like me. Report is 2000-2300 words, but the topic is based on lucky draw:( Cant choose the one you like.

reviews.author: sharon tse
reviews.title: Approaches to Humanities in China Studies
reviews.comment_content: This is an introductory course on humanities study in Chinese culture. Suitable for Chinese (Mandarin/ Cantonese) speakers, although most of the content is in English. Three professors taught in the whole semester, anthropology/linguistics/ literature us covered in 1/3 of the course period. By the end off the course, you learn something from these three area of study. The readings itself may be boring but the content covered was interesting. Here is something new I learnt from the course: è‡ªæ¢­å¥³, Chinese marriage and hidden meanings for ceremonies, poem of æ¢ç§‰éˆ in "å½¢è±¡é¦™æ¸¯", writings of Eileen Chang, graphic symbols of Chinese scripts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Hard to comment on the professors. Prof. Sun was a bit boring in his presentations, and he had a Chinese accent, but his teaching was clear and easy to follow. Many Chinese characters examples were used in the PPT. Professor Liu had years of practical field experience, so real-life examples and photos he took are used in his teaching. Prof. Shaw had very nice English. Three professors delivered the lessons quite differently.
reviews.comment_grading: There were GCS students taking the course, seems to be a required (or elective) course for them. As a Business school students, this may have affected my grade a bit. Although I did all the homework and attended quiz, I didn't read more than 1/4 of the readings during the course, except before quizzes, I still got a B as a final grade. Seems that your major background cannot define your grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload was not big. 2 Quiz (Linguistics+Anthropology) + 2 Assignment (Anthropology+Literature) throughout the whole semester. For the quizzes, study the PPT and readings and that's all. For the anthropology assignment, we were asked to interview an elderly (Anyone, can be your grandparents) and describe his/her life in 1000-2000 words. In the literature assignment, we had to write a proposal of a few pages on literature study. I spent one week in library for this assignment.
